question.title: Why this.method still works transactionally in Spring Boot
question.body:
Why do this.methodA() and this.methodB() appear to join methodD's transaction? Normally, this.method() calls bypass Spring's proxy mechanism, and @Transactional would be ignored for such calls.

Each method should execute in non-transactional context

public interface AopProxy<T> {
    default T self() {
        return (T)AopContext.currentProxy();
    }
}

@Slf4j
@Service
public class TestTransactionalService implements AopProxy<TestTransactionalService> {
    @Autowired
    private DataSource dataSource;

    @Transactional(rollbackFor = Exception.class)
    public void methodA() {
        System.out.println("methodA");
        logTransactionInfo();
    }

    @Transactional(rollbackFor = Exception.class)
    public void methodB() {
        System.out.println("methodB");
        logTransactionInfo();
    }

    @Transactional(rollbackFor = Exception.class)
    public void methodC() {
        self().methodA();
        self().methodB();
        System.out.println("methodC");
        logTransactionInfo();
    }

    @Transactional(rollbackFor = Exception.class)
    public void methodD() {
        System.out.println(this.getClass().getName());
        this.methodA();
        this.methodB();
        System.out.println("methodD");
        logTransactionInfo();
    }

    public void logTransactionInfo() {
        boolean isActive = TransactionSynchronizationManager.isActualTransactionActive();
        System.out.println("Is transaction active? " + isActive);

        String transactionName = TransactionSynchronizationManager.getCurrentTransactionName();
        System.out.println("Transaction name: " + transactionName);

        Integer isolationLevel = TransactionSynchronizationManager.getCurrentTransactionIsolationLevel();
        System.out.println("Isolation level: " + isolationLevel);

        java.sql.Connection connection = DataSourceUtils.getConnection(dataSource);
        System.out.println("Connection hashCode: " + connection.hashCode());
    }
}

@RunWith(SpringRunner.class)
@SpringBootTest
@EnableAspectJAutoProxy(exposeProxy = true, proxyTargetClass = true)
@Slf4j
public class OrderManagementTest {
    @Autowired
    private TestTransactionalService testTransactionalService;

    @Before
    public void setUp() {

    }

    @Test
    public void testTransactionalC() {
        testTransactionalService.methodC();
    }

    @Test
    public void testNoTransactionalD() {
        testTransactionalService.methodD();
    }

}

testNoTransactionalD method output with same connection:

methodA
Is transaction active? true
Transaction name: org.o2.order.server.TestTransactionalService.methodD
Isolation level: null
Connection hashCode: 1232075168
methodB
Is transaction active? true
Transaction name: org.o2.order.server.TestTransactionalService.methodD
Isolation level: null
Connection hashCode: 1232075168
methodD
Is transaction active? true
Transaction name: org.o2.order.server.TestTransactionalService.methodD
Isolation level: null
Connection hashCode: 1232075168

I know testTransactionalC method would work in the same transaction with AopContext.currentProxy(), but why testNoTransactionalD method still outputs the same connection hashCode, does it mean methodA and methodB work in the same transaction?

question_comments.body: "Each method should execute in non-transactional context" - well then... run then FROM a non-transactional context.
And you could simple inject yourself with @Lazy annotation to get aop aware instance of self as well as get it directly from ApplicationContext instead of using AopProxy

You would see behavior similar to what you thing what should happen when you remove @Transactional from methodC and methodD. Then indeed method C will start 2 transactions - for a and b, but D will (probably) not. Why probably? because it also depends on how proxy is created,
Transaction is thread bound, Since it is the same thread........

Calling methodD started a transaction (due to its @Transactional), which will end when methodD returns, so that transaction is still there when methodA and methodB are called. I'm not sure why you'd think otherwise.
